comments.commentBody:
This article fails to clarify several key points about the US healthcare system. First, physician and nurse compensation is only a very small percentage of the health care spending budget- in fact, only 8% goes to physicians. Here's a link to a research study done by Jackson Healthcare system (http://www.jacksonhealthcare.com/media-room/news/md-salaries-as-percent-.... So Mr. Holahan needs to do his homework before making broad stroke statements.

Two, this article fails to acknowledge the fact that obtaining a US medical degree is a personal endeavor- students PAY for their degrees. Most medical school's are averaging cost of attendance's of 70-80k per year. Considering medical school is four years long, by the time most students finish school they have the equivalent of a home mortgage in loans. Now imagine ~360k debt + 3-7 years of residency training being paid 45-65k + interest on that 360k at 6.8%.

Other countries such as France that have successful single payer systems (France actually has a private insurance system too) pay for their medical student's education as well as provide them with a stipend. Additionally, physicians in France pay less tax than the general public.

Don't you think that most US medical students would take up an offer for free tuition + stipend if they make the equivalent of their single payer counterparts? They would (with the exception of students interested in traditionally high paying specialties such as Dermatology).
Immigrants to Japan buy into the health care system like everyone else. I'm pretty sure Canadians do as well.
If we plan to pay doctors less, then forgive their student loan debt as part of the bargain.

Several points:
1.) Unlike most countries with single payer systems our population is not homogenous.;
2.) Not only is our population not homogenous, our income distribution pattern is decidedly skewed;
3.) We have a population that is decidedly unhealthy -- obese, smokers, with a love for violence;
4.) We expect instantaneous service and refuse to wait in queues;
5.) We sue not for malpractice, but because we are not satisfied with our outcomes;
6.) We want steak at hamburger cost.
If we cut out the middlemen insurance companies and get reduced drug cost by competitive bidding,how can it not be less expensive?
Senator Sanders should be Venezuela's Secretary of Health
Most other countries DO allow malpractice suits. However, juries and judges don't award ridiculous damages

While it is true that US costs are far higher than in other countries (not least because the AMA is a highly effective trade union) it is also true that there are an enormous number of unnecessary treatments and tests in the US. The US is one of the only countries where doctors are allowed to own testing facilities; strangely enough, doctors who have such interests prescribe twice as many tests as doctors who don't.

The arguments against doctors' salaries miss many points:

1) Doctor's salaries are only a small part of the costs. Doctor's salaries are only about 8% of healthcare spending. Even were we to not pay doctors at all, the cost "savings" would be gone only in a few years based on average rate of rise of health care spending. Cutting doctor's salaries in half as the article alludes to would only give us a 4% savings which would be gone in 2 years.

2) Real incomes of doctors have been stagnant for a decade and for many, have DECREASED. Therefore, this is not the cause of the rising costs. To make doctors the scape goat is unjustified.

3) Opportunity cost- with between 11 and 17 years of post-high school education, longer hours than the average American could even imaging and with a group of individuals who would be very compeitive for other jobs, doctors have a very high opportunity cost to go into medicine. Add to this the lost family time and the opportunity cost is even higher. For instance I haven't been home for Christmas in 3 years. I haven't made a Thanksgiving in 5. This is just a fact of the job in the US that most dont realize. Hospitals don't close.

4) Stress- there are few jobs that deal with life and death situations and this wears on a person.

If you want to cut salaries, don't expect to have the quality of candidates going into medical school.
If think the election turns on the death penalty issue, then you haven't been paying attention.

Dear David,
I don't think the election turns on the death penalty. i think the inability of the Times liberal columnist to say anything negative about Clinton, throwing out one ridiculous rationalization after another, makes us all that much more vulnerable to the potential damage of a Clinton Presidency. That Trump would be infinitely worse doesn't diminish the nightmare wars, punitive laws, violations of civil liberties and neo liberal economic policies that a Clinton administration will very likely issue in.

What Robert Roth says:

"What will Hillary Clinton do now that one of her favorite issues--support for the death penalty--was given such a serious blow. .... No wonder it is an issue so dear to her heart. Then I imagined Blow and Krugman celebrating Clinton's leadership abilities to make common cause with like minded Republicans to find some ways around the ban."

What Hillary Clinton said at the primary debate on February 4, 2016:

"Q: You said that capital punishment has a place in a very few federal cases, but you also said you would breathe a sigh of relief if the Supreme Court abolished the death penalty nationwide.

CLINTON: What I hope the Supreme Court will do is make it absolutely clear that any state that continues capital punishment must meet the highest standards of evidentiary proof of effective assistance of counsel. I have much more confidence in the federal system, and I do reserve it for particularly heinous crimes in the federal system, like terrorism. I thought it was appropriate after a very thorough trial that Timothy McVeigh received the death penalty for blowing up the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people, including 19 children in a daycare center."

While I would prefer that Hillary were in favor of abolishing the death penalty entirely, her words in the response above are hardly those of someone for whom the death penalty is "an issue dear to her heart."

I might as well get this out of my system. When as a result of public pressure, Pfizer announced that it would no longer sell drugs to be used for executions I  immediately flashed onto Krugman and Charles Blow. I thought look at this. What will Hillary Clinton do now that one of her favorite issues--support for the death penalty--was given such a serious  blow. After all Bill Clinton helped secure his presidency by executing Ricky Ray Rector. No wonder it is an issue so dear to her heart. Then I imagined Blow and Krugman celebrating Clinton's leadership abilities to make common cause with like minded Republicans to find some ways around the ban. It doesn't feel good to have such a negative  feeling about these two guys. Imagining the worst from them when they have the capacity to be much better than that.

Frankly, I'm not surprised that pro-Trump supporters are on here calling it a "hit piece", and the NYT a "partisan", "liberal" rag.  My question is, did any of these people actually read this story or they latching on to the denial from the first woman featured in this story?  This is a story of a pretty model type who is taken advantage of by a skeezy rich old man.  She wouldn't have been at the party if she wasn't pretty and she wouldn't have been with him if he wasn't rich. She's scared now that he might attack her now, like he does all women who speak truthfully about him?  Maybe.  There are dozens of interview in here about women who worked with him, by him, some who admire and a lot that don't.  The article was enlightening, specially the story on Ivana's assault, how he criticized and humiliated the pageant contestants.  Without even reading the article, I already knew that he takes advantage of women, humiliates women, mentors a few (woo hoo he's a secret angel!) but his track record is clear. I wouldn't want my kids anywhere near this sexist, racist, ignorant pompous man.  I am eagerly awaiting his defeat.

Ms Brewer Lane has publicly objected to the misleading characterization of her interactions with Mr. Trump.  Although I'm not a supporter of Trump, this article is intentionally misrepresenting her situation.

Well said, Ken H. Though you must know that he'd be perfectly thrilled if a powerful man degraded and debased his daughters. He's done it multiple times himself to his own children. I can only agree, as other women are quoted as saying in this article: gross.

Hillary is an appendage to Bill.  She has no accomplishments that are not derivative to her relationship to Bill.  That is why she has no appeal to young women.  They see plenty of female role models who are not hangers on to their husbands' success.

Memories fade and how we remember events can change over time, but listening to her she doesn't sound like a woman whose mind is so weak that she doesn't understand that she was being objectified as is implied by many here.  Ms. Brewer describes Trump as a gentleman.  It's interesting to see how hard it is for people to believe that he could actually have behaved gentlemanly towards her based on his (mostly extremely inappropriate - so extreme that it is surreal) behavior on the campaign trail, but is the campaign trail much more than a fake show anyway?
"this story smelled bad right from the beginning" - agree!

OpenMinded you need to read the full context of  the rape comment made by his first wife and her own retraction of those statements. Of course the liberals will say that she was forced to or paid to or whatever- because they want and need as much ammunition as possible. Of course this is a hit piece. Just read the title. Yes he WAS a playboy. He admits it. It doesn't mean he is one now. Where was the outcry from the left when Clinton was engaging in all of his playboy activities? Even during his political reign? Nope- we all were supposed to be tolerant and forgiving- after all- that was his private life- and who hasn't screwed up?  It's a double standard that the left seems blind to.

And now Rowanne Brewer tells Fox that the NYT spun her story, that Trump treated her well. Oh well...Another  NYT job to support Clinton turns out to increase Trump's popularity as a victim of bad journalism. Great NYT!
More and more it does seem that the secret agenda of the New York media is to get Trump elected. A Trump Presidency will double their bottom line.

What happened, NYT? what was the motivation behind this piece? I have a hard time having faith in the fourth estate?

The media by going overboard in the coronation of Hillary Clinton is going to inadvertently make Donald Trump the president of USA. I warn you. Mark my words. The more you pander to the queen, the more you are being obvious and the more people are losing their respect for you all - The NYT, MS NBC, FOX, CNN have become ridiculous.

This was so evident that you were trying to buttress the woman card argument for Mrs Clinton by making Mr. Trump look bad. And it has back-fired so badly that two respected journalists end up looking pathetic.

How about a piece on Mr. Clinton?

I hope Sanders runs as a third party candidate - he has such a great chance of winning.

Ms Lane's current comments are not crucial to my opinion & understanding of Trump's repulsive behavior toward women. She is not arguing whether or not he did these things, just how it should be interpreted, right? His ex-wife also disavows that he raped her, which I highly suspect is at least partly because she does not want to be raked over the coals by Trump & his followers, and so many clueless misogynists who don't believe that a married woman can be raped by her husband. Not to mention, that she'd not just be going against any rich & powerful man, but the Republican contender for President, and her own daughter who's campaigning for him.

The women who experienced Trump's actions can provide all kinds of excuses. We know though, his thoughts & actions are sexist and damaging to women. The best he can say about women in the work-place is that we may be efficient and productive in the best possible case, but only bc we have something to prove. This is clearly NOT supporting women. It's creating and relying on a sexist environment and using women to work harder than any man just to gain some respect & keep their jobs. It's sick. We err by relying on what women in his orbit say publicly. They have a right to their own interpretation &/or to do damage control. But their stories show a man who objectifies and hurts women as a matter of course. Just one more reason he is a complete horror show.

"Just more proof that he does whatever he thinks is in his own best interest"  Gee, hiring smart capable women to top positions who he know will work hard thanks to institutional sexism, what an awful, horrible move for him.  Especially if it helps his business stay afloat so that he can sign the paychecks (little details that government workers don't have to worry about as much, true).   19 trillion dollars, and counting! Wheee!!!!
What's more and is very apparent, AY, is that he obviously doesn't care.

I agree with most of your comment, gianna, except the one about Sen. Sanders not being able 'to attract female voters over a certain age.' I'm 57 and I agree with his vision of what our country, and the world, can and should be.

Maybe it takes someone who's still young at heart?
Read the article again. His first wife said the rape story was totally without merit.

Hate to say this but this was a slimy "got you" piece of poor journalism. There are so many other issues you could go after Trump, but you chose this topic for some strange reason? Not a fan of both parties and I truly hope you spend as much time and money on Clinton's past.

I expect better, and as a subscriber for a long time I hope this was a one time mistake.

Please do your research better and don't forget the Clinton's.

Nick
